function_call.name: classify_risks_framework
function_call.arguments: {"sorted_risks":[{"name":"Population growth and urbanization contributing to the risk of malaria transmission in the global south.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Deforestation increases the prevalence of the malaria vector, leading to a higher risk of malaria transmission.","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Increased rainfall leads to increased prevalence of the anopheles vector, resulting in a greater need for malaria control strategies.","category":"Structure","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Data paucity and lack of actionable insights hinder the characterization of the magnitude and complexity of the malaria problem, particularly in the context of climate change and urbanization.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Artificial breeding sites such as drains, gutters, swimming pools, and tire tracks can pose a risk for increased larvae development and greater mosquito population density.","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Urbanization increases demand for intervention technologies, leading to greater demand for malaria prevention products.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium"},{"name":"Low socioeconomic status and poverty are significant risk factors for malaria transmission due to reduced opportunities for education and lack of access to disease treatment.","category":"Society","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Geographic residence plays a role in malaria transmission, with different anopheles species prevalent in specific regions, creating varying demand for intervention technologies.","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Deforestation from land use contributes to climate change, potentially altering the geographic distribution of disease vectors.","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Link between increased construction activities and risk of malaria infection","category":"Structure","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Urbanization as a reinforcing factor on constraints to the use of insecticide-treated nets itns as an intervention strategy","category":"Interactions","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Artificial breeding sites in the built environment as a source factor for malaria transmission","category":"Structure","confidence":"High"},{"name":"Overlap between public health champions and construction trades may limit the effectiveness of housing modification for malaria control.","category":"Society","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Failure to develop concerted efforts for the future in addressing malaria transmission.","category":"Society","confidence":"Medium-high"},{"name":"Lack of involvement of built environment professionals in malaria intervention
